You must answer on the question paper.

You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions

INSTRUCTIONS
• Answer all questions.
• Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.
• Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.
• Write your answer to each question in the space provided.
• Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.
• Do not write on any bar codes.
• You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.
• You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.
• You may use a calculator.
• You should show all your working and use appropriate units.

INFORMATION
• The total mark for this paper is 40.
• The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

1 In this experiment, you will investigate a light-dependent resistor (LDR).
(a)
• Connect the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1.

[Image Fig. 1.1 description: A circuit diagram. A 1.5 V power source (cell) is connected in series with a switch S, a resistor, and an ammeter A. The LDR is connected in parallel with the resistor (though drawn in series with the cell and ammeter, it appears to be acting as the primary resistance in the external circuit, possibly representing the variable resistance of the LDR in series with an ammeter and a fixed resistor, although the fixed resistor symbol is used adjacent to the ammeter). The LDR itself is shown partially inserted into a cardboard tube. The tube entry is flush with the front face of the LDR. Labels include "1.5 V", "S", "cardboard tube", "LDR leads", "tape", and "LDR (inside tube)". The ammeter is labelled 'A'.]

Fig. 1.1

• Ensure that the switch S is open.
• Slide the LDR leads into the tube until the front of the LDR is just level with the open end of the tube, as shown in Fig. 1.1.
• With the LDR in this position, attach a piece of adhesive tape to the leads as a marker at the other end of the tube, as shown in Fig. 1.1.
• Slide the tube until the LDR is approximately half-way along it, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

[Image Fig. 1.2 description: A side view of the LDR leads with the adhesive tape marker, connected to the cardboard tube with the LDR inside. The distance 'x' is defined as the distance between the tape marker and the end of the tube where the leads emerge. Labels include "x" and "tape".]

Fig. 1.2

(b) Change x by moving the LDR to a new position inside the tube, with x in the range 4 cm to
18 cm. Record x and I.
Repeat until you have six sets of values of x and I.
Record your results in a table. Include values of $\sqrt{I}$ in your table.

[10]
(c) (i) Plot a graph of $\sqrt{I}$ on the y-axis against x on the x-axis.
[3]
(ii) Draw the straight line of best fit.
[1]
(iii) Determine the gradient and y-intercept of this line.
gradient = ..........................................................
y-intercept = ......................................................
[2]

$\sqrt{I}$ = $ax + b$
where $a$ and $b$ are constants.

Using your answers in (c)(iii), determine the values of $a$ and $b$.
Give appropriate units.

$a$ = .....................................................................
$b$ = .....................................................................

2 In this experiment, you will investigate the elastic properties of rubber cord.
(a) (i) You are provided with a wire with a clip and two slotted masses attached, as shown in
Fig. 2.1.

[Image Fig. 2.1 description: A diagram showing a wire bent into a shallow U-shape, held by a clip at the apex. Two slotted masses are attached to the two hanging ends of the wire. The distance B is shown horizontally between the centers of the two slotted masses. Labels: "clip", "wire", "mass", "B".]

Fig. 2.1

The distance between the centres of the two slotted masses is B, as shown in Fig. 2.1.
Measure and record B.

B = .....................................................................
[1]

(ii) Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of B. Show your working.

percentage uncertainty = .................................................... % [1]

© UCLES 2025
9702/32/M/J/25
[Turn over
</page 7>

<page 8>
* 0000800000008 *
8
(b) (i)
• You are provided with two lengths of rubber cord. Select the longer cord.
• The diameter of the cord is $d$.
Measure and record $d$.
$d$ = .....................................................................
[1]
(ii)
• Suspend the clip, wire and masses using the longer cord secured in the two clips,
as shown in Fig. 2.2.

[Image Fig. 2.2 description: A vertical stand setup. A stand supports a boss, which holds a clamp. The jaws of the clamp grip an upper clip. A rubber cord hangs vertically down from the upper clip, secured at the bottom by a lower clip. The wire with masses (as shown in Fig. 2.1) is suspended from the lower clip. The length L is the vertical distance along the rubber cord between the upper clip and the lower clip. A bench is indicated below the masses. Labels: "stand", "boss", "jaws of clamp", "upper clip", "rubber cord", "lower clip", "wire with masses attached", "bench", "L". The diagram is noted as (not to scale).]

Fig. 2.2 (not to scale)

• The length of cord between the two clips is L, as shown in Fig. 2.2.
Measure and record L.

L = .....................................................................
[1]

(iii)
• Keeping the cord vertical, rotate the lower clip through approximately 180° and
release the clip. The clip will rotate with a small number of oscillations.
• Take measurements to determine the period T of these oscillations.
T = .................................................... s [2]

(c) Using the shorter length of rubber cord, repeat (b).
$d$ = .....................................................................
$L$ = .....................................................................
$T$ = .................................................... s [3]

(d) It is suggested that the relationship between T, B, L and $d$ is
$T^2 = \frac{B^2 L}{kd^4}$
where $k$ is a constant.

(i) Using your data, calculate two values of $k$.

first value of $k$ = ..........................................................
second value of $k$ = ........................................................
[1]

(ii) Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your values of $k$.
